access.accessibility_details: Uphill walk through village required, not wheelchair accessible
access.public_transport_access: Train to Riomaggiore, uphill walk through village

details.description_long: The Church of San Giovanni Battista rises in the upper part of Riomaggiore village. Built in 1340 at the behest of Antonio Fieschi, bishop of Luni, it represents important Ligurian Gothic architecture. The original work by Antelami Masters of Lombard origin is visible in the rose window of white Carrara marble and the Gothic side doors with decorative lunettes. The church underwent major renovation in 1870 when the facade was rebuilt in Neo-Gothic style, though the original rose window was preserved. The church was extended by one span during these works. Inside, important features include a carved marble pulpit, a painted wooden crucifix, and a Renaissance triptych. The northern part of the building leans against the hillside.
details.description_short: Historic 14th-century church with Neo-Gothic facade and beautiful Carrara marble rose window, located in Riomaggiore's upper village.
details.architectural_style: Neo-Gothic facade with original Gothic elements
details.historical_significance: Built by Bishop Antonio Fieschi, represents Antelami Masters craftsmanship, major restoration in 1870

directions.from_harbor: Climb main street (Via Colombo) uphill to upper village square
directions.from_train_station: Walk uphill through main street to upper village, church is in central piazza

location.location_description: Upper part of village, preceded by vast paved square

popularity.best_time_to_visit: Morning or evening, beautiful at night with lights

opening_hours.notes: Open during day, closed during services. Beautiful lit up at night from outside.

insider_tips: Walk up at night for beautiful village views with church lit up
Look for the triptych of Master of Cinque Terre
practical_tips.what_to_wear: Modest clothing, comfortable shoes for uphill walk
photography_tips: Bas-reliefs above side doors are remarkable
